subject: Re: [junit] Integration of JUnit in existing software-systems

messageBody:
Coolspot714 wrote:

> Hello everybody,
>
> I'd like to hear your opinions on a rather general subject. I'm a
> student and I'm doing a research about how JUnit could be used in my
> company to improve the efficiency of software development. What my
> bosses, not knowing a lot about JUnit, only having heard of it, first
> wanted to have was a piece of software which tests an existing
> application on a technical level. (like "one Button tests all")

It is impossible to write software that tests other software. I don't
know the proof, but then, I don't need to be convinced. :)

> >From what I know now, JUnit is a framework for the developer to
> improve the quality of the application and to avoid failures in the
> code which might otherwise be overseen.

That sounds about right.

> Now here's my question: does
> it make sense to take an existing application and try to write test
> cases/suites for it?

Does it make sense? Absolutely. Why not have more confidence in the
correctness of your software?

Does it make sense for /this/ company, in /these/ market conditions,
/now/? That depends. Like anything else, the company needs to decide how
to spend its money, and testing existing software may or may not be high
enough on the priority list.

The need to test existing software is, in my opinion, a function of the
need to change it. Changing software without tests is expensive because
it's slow going (programmers are afraid to make the changes) and prone
to error (programmers are right to be afraid). It is much easier and
safer to change software when, after each change, I can run a suite of
tests that can tell me about the impact of my change. Since we spend
most of our time changing existing software, it is common to want/need
to test existing software.

> The application is a rather abstract one

Applications can't be abstract. Frameworks are abstract, and
applications are concrete.

> ...it's a
> middleware component (API) between one big and several smaller
> applications, it consist of several EJBs with basically lots of get-
> Methods, using JAX-RPC SOAP and RMI.

Whether it's middleware or not, you must be able to define "working" or
"not working" for various parts of the components. If you can do that,
then you can write tests.

> I doubt it makes sense, but I don't have a lot of experience about
> what JUnit is capable of and how the code would have to be refactored.

Why don't you think it makes sense? What are three reasons you wouldn't
write tests for this code?

> I guess it would make more sense telling the developers why and how
> to use JUnit in order to improve things in FUTURE developments and to
> stick with the old code without JUnit. What do you think?

This is a common strategy: add tests to existing code /only/ when you
need to change the existing code. This helps us spend only the money we
know we need to spend on testing existing code. Often, this minimizes
the cost of maintaining the existing code.

> PS: Sorry I can't give you more information about the application I
> was talking about, I'm still in the process of understanding how it
> works and I'm not a Java-pro (yet:-).

Understood.
